posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked:
What’s everyone’s thoughts on these JST JWPF 2-Way connector for CAN connections?

We currently use the stock 3 pin PWM connectors with clips, but I’ve never been a fan of those like many here. We also recieved sponsorship from Corsa Technic for next year, so I’d like to use something they stock.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
I don’t know if many teams are fans of 3 pin PWM cables.

Your connector there looks good, and might be easy to crimp as well. I would say it’s probably as good as any other solution - done right, you won’t have problems.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
We used some similar (Molex) locking 2-pin connectors for a few years (and still do on certain connections) but we’ve started avoiding them due to the poor-quality crimps we got on them (the wires would pull out of the crimp). That said, the pins on these look closer to the ones you would see on a PWM-style connection (which seem to be more durable), so maybe you’ll have better luck than we did?

Also, BTW, those JST connectors appear to be a bit cheaper on DigiKey

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: The ones you linked there are Molex SL, which usually crimp well. What crimp tool do you use? Hansen Hobbies resells these (Locking PWM I think) and their crimpers do a good job.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
I have also used the Molex connectors purchased from Hansen Hobbies on a previous team. We had mixed success and it took a lot of my time to inspect every crimp the team members made to ensure that they were good. Once they passed my inspection, they were good for the rest of the season.

With my current team, team members are invited to train to join the electrical team after they had been observed to be careful and meticulous when doing mechanical construction. I have not found a way to teach people to be careful or meticulous, on an FRC team or in the workplace. Once we showed the selected team members what was a bad connection, they could be heard to say something like “No, you wouldn’t want that”. I only did some random checks and missed doing an overall check of the integrity of the electrical system prior to our competitions. We didn’t have any connection failures all 4 events that were due to the quality of the workmanship.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
These are the Crimpers we have:

PWM Crimping Tool for use on 18-30 AWG wires

They work but are easy to get wrong if you’re not careful and the wires pull out of the crimps over time. The housings are also short enough that if both wires pull out slightly it doesn’t take much to short them to each other.

asid61:

Grammar is hard. I intended to say I dislike the connector just like many people on here dislike the connector.
